reviewText:
Remember the nights you played Resident Evil Zero on Gamecube? No? I do.

This game is right for you ...

... when you walk through a dark corridor and you do not know what to expect around the next corner ...
... when you see a shadow and you do not know if its just furniture or the monster you don't want to meet ...
... when you suddenly hear a creepy moan behind the next wall and you're to scared to move forward ...

First of all here are some simple steps to make sure you get the whole creepy experience out of this game:

- Use a controller (although you can use the keyboard, which is not really recommendable - atleast for me. I don't like it, you could)

- Play at night (or darken your room), you will feel very uncomfortable, trust me

- Don't rush the game like hell. Take your time, explore everything and feel yourself into the world.

- forget everything about Resident Evil 5, 6, RC:O and similiar games. This is clearly not the same. This is real horror.

So what is Resident Evil 0?

Resident Evil Zero is the prequel to all the beginning of Resident Evil 1 and the following games.
Its the 07.23.1998, the day before the deadly virus was released in Raccoon City.
This game is full of interesting puzzles, a good story and an oppressive atmosphere.


Pros:

+++ Scary game that will make you feel very lonely and lost
+++ A good background story about what happened before Resident Evil 1
+++ hours of fun playing this game
++ you can play 2 characters
++ a lot of puzzles
+ you can choose the difficulty
+ the new HD graphics
+ controls
+ cheap price, for 20 â‚¬ really worth it

neutral (i like these stuff, but there are many people who actually hate this old fashioned gameplay):

+- this game can be really challenging and frustrating, especially when you're new to this kind of a game
+- characters move very slowly, that is not up to date for a modern game
+- camera angles

Cons:

- unfortunately no new improvement
- you have to pay for costumes
- some bugs like sometimes audio crashing in cut scenes
- if you don't have a good pc this game may run in a slow motion which just feels not smooth
- it may cause a heart attack

What is special about this game?

This Oldschool-Horror Survival Game comes first time with 2 Characters that you can control. (Yes, Resident 5 and so on had also multiple characters). The special thing about these two characters is both of them have their special skills. Rebecca can't take a lot of damage, but she can mix herbs, which can be very useful. Billy got a lighter, which can be helpful for some things. In addition he can take a lot more damage before he will die. In the most time you are playing together, while you can decide with whom you move. You can also decide if your partner will support you in the fight or if he will even follow you or rather stay on his position. This gameplay with both characters CAN make you feel a bit more safe, but don't lean back that much because there will be several situations where you both are lost and on your own, trying to find each other of you. In this case you will feel very lost and desperate. This makes this game so special. You have to keep an eye on both characters, make them survive this game. If one of your characters dies, the game is over.

How good is the new HD graphic?

While the original Resident Evil Zero on Gamecube was very old fashioned and mushy, this new remastered version comes with some new effects. The game overall looks way better than the old version but you can still see some ugly details which doesn't look that great. Just dont expect too much. It looks just fine, but there is nothing sensational about it. It can be kinda compared with Resident Evil 1 Remastered.

My final words:

This lets me conclude that this game is really good and it is a REAL Resident Evil. Its not a shooter like the newer games. This game is hard, can be frustrating and brings a lot of fun. You will feel like you felt in Resident Evil 1-3, i will guarantee you. If you never played Resident Evil, but you're a fan of horror-games, then i can also recommend this game for you. For people who want a modern game with a GREAT graphics and a lot of shooting, i really can't recommend this to you, because you might be disapppointed.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 0 was the ninth game in the titanically influential series and arguably the last to showcase a style that modern gaming was fast leaving behind. The pre-drawn environments, the fixed camera angles, the creaky door cinematics that covered the loading times between areas, having to stand in exactly the right bloody spot to pick up an item... they would all disappear quickly after Zero, leaving the radically different masterpiece that was Resident Evil 4 to pick up the pieces.

Even so, Capcom had already begun to change their gameplan here, introducing a buddy system in which the player freely shared control of the game's two main characters: S.T.A.R.S medic Rebecca Chambers (who you might remember from RE1 as the mostly useless pianist who rescued Chris Redfield's cack-fingered attempts to play Moonlight Sonata) and convicted ex-soldier Billy Coen. Although control of multiple characters was nothing new in the franchise, here it was the centerpiece of the game as most of the puzzles and combat scenarios are engineered to require each character's strengths and to prey on their weaknesses.

I played Resident Evil 0 to death when it originally made its appearance on the Gamecube back in 2002 and, although it did truly rock some ingenuous design, the controls were an absolute horror show especially in any combat scenario. If you've spent any time with the original version, you'll immediately notice how far improved they are in this remaster along with some truly stunning visuals. I'm a sucker for the pre-drawn background art style and it has never looked better than it does here. Also added for a bonus playthrough is Wesker Mode which really does what it says on the tin: blaze through the game as Johnny Bravo's evil twin, sneering and shadow-punching zombies into twitching mulch.

Remaining unchanged, however, is the game's notorious inventory system which truly is the most unforgiving in the entire series. You will often find yourself having to leave useful items behind for sheer lack of carrying space which can mostly be blamed on the Hookshot; a vital piece of equipment that has to be dragged through much of the game while occupying a gluttonous two squares of inventory room. The sheer amount of micromanagement between characters, especially with only Rebecca being able to create healing items, was a pain in â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ then and it's a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ now.

With that said, whatever faults Resident Evil 0 might suffer are relatively minor. It's one of the weaker titles in the franchise but it's certainly far better than the catastrophe that was RE6 and when you consider that it's only really weak in comparison to the mighty original trilogy, the excellent Code Veronica and REMake and the near-flawless Resident Evil 4, well... that's barely a criticism at all really.

This gives me hope for the Resident Evil 2 Remake. Capcom is on the right track.

Update: For those concerning with more detail in this review, simply put the fact that it places Resident Evil right back in its roots; actual survival horror and not a third-person shooter in which enemies drop ammo. I won't say much about the story other than the fact that it is classic Resident Evil cheesiness all over again, but hey that's what Resident Evil does best.

Overall it's a damn good Resident Evil game and if the Resident Evil 2 Remake heads in this direction with its own new gameplay mechanics and seamless integration for both scenarios A and B, Capcom will surely rise once again. Here's to the next true Resident Evil game!

Resident Evil 0 is both good and bad in so many ways, and some of them arenâ€™t even related to this HD remaster. Iâ€™m a Resident Evil junkie, and I have been since I got hooked on the PSX original back in 1996, after reading a review of it in Game Informer, one of those things called magazines that you had to buy at stores or wait for it to arrive by mail.

Resident Evil 0 was the last â€œrealâ€ Resident Evil, a slow and methodical game, before Capcom decided the non-stop action and set pieces were the way to go. Not a knock against Resident Evil 4, though. RE4 was a terrific game, it just wasnâ€™t a terrific Resident Evil game.

That said, Resident Evil 0 HD Remaster is a fantastic remaster. It shines on PC. The enhanced graphics bring the backgrounds to life, you can read signs and notices that were blurry on the GameCube version, the story (while not the best in the series) does an excellent job of providing more background on Umbrella, and while it introduced a couple of new things to the series (character switching, ability to drop items), it also removed some (such as item boxes).

I'm here to briefly (and straight to the point) tell you about the quality of the Remaster itself. Spoiler-free.
The entire game is one huge eyecandy, every background has been re-rendered, they're at way more higher resolution and do not have obvious compression artifacts. Moving parts of the backgrounds, lighting, shadows, item icons, some 3D objects and bloom were drastically improved along with some character model and font tweaks. The only semi-original things that are left in are the FMV cutscenes which were also cropped accordingly. Just like in RE1HD you can rebind KB&M controls to your liking (with the exception of mouse, it seems, as it's used for aiming and shooting by default).

The game itself is mostly left unchanged, but it has a couple of extra bonuses added like the Wesker mode where you use RE5 Wesker's special abilities to battle BOWs. This mode is unlocked when you finish the game at least once. There are also extra purchasable DLC costumes if you're into that sorta thing. Worth mentioning that this game supports achievements some of which are rather creative.

As for port itself it's the superior version among the platforms offering you variable framerate refresh rate, 4K resolution, but for whatever reason lacks DoF (blur in distance) which is currently present on PS4. For some with weak/machines with compatibility issues the game might run in slow motion (if you had this issue with RE4UHD, RE1HD then you'll likely have it here). Also currently there's bug with doors stuttering a bit when opened, likely a cache issue (not present on newer graphics cards).

If you care about Survival Horror in this industry and/or oldschool RE then you should pick this up.

Let me know in the comments if I missed something or something needs a correction.

Serving as a prequel to the first game Resident Evil 0 sees STARS member Rebecca Chambers and convict Billy Coen join forces to try and survive the dangers ahead while uncovering Umbrella's plans.
As a throwback to old-school survival horror RE0 is a pretty competent albeit lazy and fiddly game that is quite fun to play.

PROS:

-it really looks nice with overhauled 3d models, backgrounds and effects

-good soundtrack

-having two characters at your disposal, and being able to freely switch between them, is nice

-sheds some light on the events of the first Resident Evil

-some interesting puzzles

-being able to leave items anywhere is nice

-certain sections can be appropriately tense

NEUTRAL:

-as in most RE games expect cheesy characters and plot

-per RE standards expect unskippable door animations between rooms

-while for the most part competent your companion's AI can sometimes hesitate too much

-somewhat forgettable bosses

CONS:

-movies look a bit dated and low-res

-a couple annoying puzzles

-inventory management can be fiddly

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=631132768

Resident Evil 0's HD remaster is truly noticeable as the game looks great, the mechanics are still the same though (apart from a leaner control scheme) so you can expect a very old fashioned gameplay with all the pros and cons. To expand on that you'll find a pretty atmospheric and challenging survival horror experience with familiar puzzles, quite a few items to carry back and forth to solve them, very limited inventory space and a good amount of bioweapons that'll try to kill you.

The whole item management aspect is part of the old-school charm but can also feel unnecessary fiddly at times, especially when you find out there's a limit to how many items you can leave in each room or have to make a few trips to ensure you have all the items you need in the next area. Story and characters are also pretty shallow and don't really add too many interesting elements to the overarching narrative.

All things considered RE0 is still a worthwhile purchase if you're looking for more old-style survival horror and even more so if you missed it when it came out on Gamecube: it's not the strongest entry of the series but it's decent enough to warrant a playthrough.

I didn't get into Resident Evil Games until 6 was released but have played the remake of 1 and the revelations games thoroughly. I am now hooked and was already a fan of the films.

Also upon completion you get a new game mode collecting leeches, a bit like the revelations extra modes. There is also a Wesker mode, where you play though the game again, but Billy looks and sounds like Wesker. A bit odd but enough to make you playthrough again, especially as there are added achievements. I will probably leave the game mostly after my first completion though, as I have plenty of other games to finish or even start.

I think this is a great addition to the franchise and adds enough to the story and variety of gameplay to make it a worthy addition for all the RE veterans collections.

reviewText:
Capcom one again brings a classic title to Steam in full HD Glory, an overlooked gem from 2002. They completely remastered every background this time because they had access to the original game files so that's a plus. Everything from the original is carried over along with a few extras made exclusively for the remaster itself.

New stuff included in the Remaster include:
- Wesker Mode (Beat the game once on any difficulty to unlock)
- Full HD Backgrounds
- Gallery Mode (Includes all the game FMV's, Unlocked from the start and progresses as you do)
- 60 fps (PC Exclusive) consoles are locked to 30, variable frame rate is included.
- New control scheme similar to the action games, various layouts to choose from
- Exclusives costumes, were shown as in game but are actually paid DLC which is typical Capcom
- 5 fan made t-shirts for free if you voted during the campaign

Already played through the entire campaign and Leech Mode and I had no issues with the gameplay itself. Mechanic/story wise nothing was changed from the original 2002 release which isn't a bad thing. Capcom attempted to bring co-op to the game but it didn't work, pretty obvious why it wouldn't work.

Item Management is very different from other RE games, this one elimates the need for Item Boxes completely from the start. Newcomers will probably hate the constant backtracking to find items they dropped but old school players will feel right at home. If you are having issues locating items go into your Map and turn on the UI, for some reason reviewers didn't mention this and people are having issues finding it.

Graphic options are pretty much the game as Remake Remastered from last year, according to most people the backgrounds are locked to 1440 resolution again. Running the game on max settings I was able to play through the entire game without slowdown except the area where you meet your first leech, I think there's a bug here with the flame effects. Other than that I had a constant 60fps experience, also tried variable which for some reason locked the game to 45 fps, tried 30fps for the hell of it and it was too slow for me lol.

Overall, if you're a hardcore RE fan from the early days you should pick it up. If you're newcomer and have patience I'd reccommend trying the game out, just don't expect an action experience this one is a bit slower than the original game but it offers solid gameplay if you give it a chance. Only thing I feel needs work is the control scheme, I dunno who's idea it was to map the run button to X but that needs to be changed. They should have just given the option of using the original gamecube layout.

Resident Evil Zero was originally released on Gamecube in 2002, and was also ported to the Wii in 2008. I never played either of those versions, which means I can't really comment on how faithful this HD remake is, so I will simply judge this version on its own merits. On the whole I enjoyed playing the game, although it does have some problems.

As the name suggests, Zero is a prequel to RE1. There are two playable characters, STARS member Rebecca, and convicted criminal Billy. The player can switch between them at will, with the AI controlling the other character, or you can explore with one character on their own. Billy has more health, is strong enough to move heavy objects, and has a cigarette lighter, whilst Rebecca can mix herbs and other chemicals.

Gameplay contains both the good and the bad of old school survival horror. Combat is a slower pace, there are a small number of monsters, but each one is dangerous. Resource management is key, because ammo and healing items are scarce, so you can't afford to waste any. Puzzles are intelligently designed to require both characters working together.

Unfortunately the fixed camera angles are far more annoying than I remember in RE1. There is a ridiculous number of combat encounters where the monster is off screen, my character is looking at the monster, but I can't see what they see, because I'm forced to look at my character, which makes aiming more difficult than it should be. Thankfully the partner AI is pretty useful, although I'm not sure if standing still while the AI shoots the monsters" qualifies as playing the game. 2) Anyway: If you pick up stuff and drop it near typewriters, the game almost plays and feels like RE1 â€œreal survivalâ€ mode, where item boxes arenâ€™t linked.

This game isn't as good as the REmaster from a year ago, but it's still great if you're looking for some more classic Resident Evil. Controlling two characters can put a damper on the game for some, but to me it just increases the tension. Item management is a bigger thing here, and there are no item boxes. However you can drop items wherever you like and use some items when picking them up, even if your inventory is full. Both characters have their own item slots (making 12 slots in total), however there are items and weapons that take up more than one slot. Not going to lie, item management can get a little sloppy at times.

Graphical enhancements are the same as what you would expect after playing the first REmaster, with some character models and pictures being redone. Controls, like the first REmaster, are completely customizable for keyboard and mouse, while controller gets five different preset controls. I recommended keyboard and mouse for the first REmaster, but I may have to recommend a controller this time. Main reason being is that you can control the other character with the other stick without having to switch to the other character. You can still control the other character with the arrow keys (or whatever keys you wish to bind them as). Also, you cannot control one character with the new control scheme (non-tank controls) and then control the other character with classic tank controls. reviewText: Resident Evil 0 is a lot of fun. It's more of the campy, gory, spooky good time we enjoy from the RE series and it offers a robust challenge. Lots of dying in this game. This is the last in the series that is essentially an action packed point-and-click adventure game and I appreciate the opportunity to play RE0 once again. Sure the puzzles are not necessarily realistic, but the whole series is always bordering on parody as it is. The level design isn't as strong as in previous titles of the series and some of the environments gave a strong sense of deja vu. The very worst thing about this game, though, is the inventory management. Holy f.ck! Each character can only hold six items and there was always a constant need to switch items between characters, leave items in a room and then have to hike all the way back for them once there was enough room in the inventory. Some items even took up two spots in the inventory. I understand this was a necessary feature for how some of the puzzles were designed, but... how dare they! There is a lot of back tracking in game simply because of the terrible inventory system. The main villain was laughably awful too. Everything he said was re-tarded and he looked like some androgynous NPC from a Final Fantasy game. Don't get me wrong, the puzzle solving, exploration, and blowing away monsters were a grand time and most of the game is spent doing these things. It took around 15 hours to finish the game for the first time. There's definitely incentive to re-play it too; and not just because it's a fun game in general either. After finishing the game for the first time, the ability to play as Wesker is unlocked. This is essentially easy mode. He has an attack that can clear a room faster than grandma's chili. It was a thrill to see groups of enemies all instantly drop dead in unison from a single blast. Boss battles became a breeze. Most only took around 3 blasts from Wesker to kill. There's another mode that wasn't as interesting to me where Rebecca and Billy need to find leech charms scattered throughout the mansion. RE0 still looks pretty good after all these years. Kudos to Capcom for the job they did polishing this game up, getting it ready for this HD release. The water animations stand out as the most impressive part of the presentation. Slime oozes from leeches, water from a filled sink splashes around dripping to the floor, and the rain beats down on top of the train all in convincing fashion, to give a few examples. Even a very simple cut-scene of water flowing from a pipe was impressive to watch. From a technical standpoint, the game ran flawlessly. The frame rate was consistently a rock solid 60fps and the game never crashed. RE0 won't win any converts to the series, but it's still a really good game that I highly recommend, even if it doesn't reach as high levels the series has previously reached.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 0 is probably the most polarizing game in the series, only beating out 6 because it's harder to find a person who genuinely enjoys 6 as a Resident Evil game than it is to find Wesker without sunglasses. Some people will tell you it's the worst non-6 game in the main series, others will tell you it's one of their favorites. I had never played it until now, so I had no idea what to think going in, but I was pleasantly surprised.

First off, for those who are just here to see the port changes, it's pretty well-done overall. The HD Remaster of REmake was put down a bit due to the developers not having original sources for most of the backdrops, so a lot of scenes looked grainy or artifacted, especially if you were playing in HD, and it made 3D geometry like items or puzzle objects stand out awkwardly. In RE0 HD this has been completely fixed, and whether you choose to play in widescreen or in the original aspect ratio everything except the cutscenes looks fantastic. The game still has the same problem with mouse and keyboard play as REmake HD did in that the cursor never goes off screen, so I did play it with a gamepad, but if you can ignore the cursor it controls fine either way. The main new addition aside from the DLC costumes is Wesker Mode, which is an amusing little extra mode where you replay the game replacing Billy with Wesker, complete with a couple of superpowered attacks.

As far as the game in general, I thought it was great. The new mechanic introduced lets you swap between two different characters, which is mainly used to add some spice to the classic Resident Evil puzzles. This means you have a larger combined inventory, but this is offset by what seems to be the most polarizing change - unlike most RE games, there is no magical transporting item box in RE0. Anything you can't carry with you has to be left on the ground somewhere, encouraging you to make caches in certain rooms. Some people will hate this change, and I can understand that, but I thought it added a lot of pressure to manage your inventory and choose carefully what to keep and what to leave behind. Any items that you've interacted with show up on your map, so it isn't a hassle to figure out where you've left something. The game is somewhat faster paced in that you start facing BOWs and acquiring weapons (though not necessarily ammo) to fight them earlier than you probably would in REmake on your first try, but it's still a more resource-scarce and survival-like game than others like Code Veronica. It is shorter than REmake by nature of only having one campaign instead of two like RE1 had, but I found 0's campaign to be a little longer than one of 1's campaigns and on your first playthrough it should serve you a fair amount of time.

In many ways it feels similar to REmake, and some locations will definitely feel familiar, but it keeps things fresh enough to feel more like an encore than a retread. My only real complaint about it is that the train portion of the game is actually fairly short and only makes up a small portion of the game, which disappointed me because I loved the look and atmosphere of it. But overall, if you're a fan of REmake, I can't see any reason not to try this as well, assuming you already haven't in the past decade or so.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 0 deserves more credit.

Of all the more traditional games in the series prior to Resident Evil 4's more action-y gameplay overhaul, 0 receives the most trash talk. It first appeared in 2002, well after all but the most ardent of fans were tired of the survival horror formula and ready for something new. Despite a few minor additions, Resident Evil 0 didn't offer that.

But that's precisely why this Resident Evil 0 HD re-release from Capcom is so useful. With distance from the atmosphere surrounding its release, it's a lot easier to view Resident Evil 0 for exactly what it is: a flawed but generally satisfying and, more importantly, smart take on Capcom's approach to horror.


And yet, aside from the very last area, I found Resident Evil 0's locales interesting enough to alleviate any frustration from backtracking. These are tightly-designed settings, paced perfectly to emphasize tension. I was rarely sent running in a direction I'd already been in without the area suddenly being invaded by a new nightmare creature, or without finding myself unexpectedly stalked by a returning foe. Even as the game advanced and I built up a healthy backpack of ammunition for my guns, I always felt just one or two bad rooms away from losing everything.

For as much as Resident Evil 0 embraces the series' classic gameplay, it also adopts the goofy, heavy-handed and poorly voice-acted storytelling of the franchise's earliest entries. If you're expecting serious drama from Rebecca and Billy, you're in for a disappointment, and don't even get me started on the game's hilariously ineffective villain. But if you love the cornier approach to survival horror, before everything took itself so seriously, it's a blast.

Removed from the moment in time when it debuted, Resident Evil 0 is just a really good classic RE game. It didn't set the standards for this style of game the way Resident Evil 1 did; it's not as ambitious or unblemished as Resident Evil 2. But it's far from the mess that history made it out to be. Whether you're a veteran who's played it before or a new fan who never tried out Resident Evil 0, it's good enough to deserve this second chance.

reviewText:
When considering what it is that distinguishes a survival horror game from an action or any other genre, things that come to mind for survival horror fans are usually locked camera angles which can often put the player at a viewing disadvantage, weak or limited combat abilities, low ammo supplies and adventure game exploration in a environment filled with dangerous enemies. What makes a survival horror game different from other genres is that while most games give the player great agency and power over the world, survival horror puts the player at a disadvantage and in a position of weakness. Under those parameters, Resident Evil Zero is undoubtedly a survival horror game.

If inconveniencing the player is part of what makes a game a survival horror game, then Resident Evil Zero may at times have too much of a good thing. While it is a staple of the classic Resident Evil franchise to give the player limited inventory and to juggle items, Zero goes a step further by flooding the player with a multitude of items while also providing no system of storage. The idea was to make item management more organic by forcing the player to pick up and put down items in the game world as necessary rather than being confined to chests. But the management of resources frequently crosses the line from being a source of tension to a source of tedium, and first time players can add whole hours to their play time as they trial and error which items they needed to take and which to leave behind.

Despite the two character co-op mechanic, this game brings nothing substantially new to the Resident Evil franchise or the survival horror genre. Many of the familiar enemies and settings seen in other games come back here and none of the features makes this game stand out compared to the other entries.  What it does bring is a solid entry into the genre and another hearty full length adventure for fans to sink their teeth into. One quality which stands out in this game versus the other classic Resident Evils is that while they have often been called survival horror, they usually ended up playing more like action games by the end. As early as Resident Evil 2 the games have been empowering the player more than the game advertises and even in the remake there is more bullets than there are enemies to kill by the end of the game. In Resident Evil Zero, especially on hard difficulty, there are truly more threats than there are resources to spare. Perhaps in trying to be how people remembered the classic Resident Evils were like rather than being how they really are, Resident Evil Zero is more survival horror than most of the other Resident Evils.

Playing Zero on hard, I was constantly on the verge of running out of ammo and I was truly worried that I might run out of supplies before I needed them. Zero will still empower the player in time for the end of the game, but first time players will be holding their breath for quite a while before that part arrives. Resident Evil Zero is not an accommodating game. Although released in 2002, this is a game with the design philosophy of 3D playstation 1 games. Many of the features and character control standards of modern AAA games are missing from this title, and it is a very real possibility to get permanently stuck. If you don't mind early 3D game mechanics however, and want to experience a survival horror challenge in what is clearly still a AAA game for its time, then I recommend Resident Evil Zero.

If you decide to play this game, I recommend that you play it on hard on your first playthrough. A big part of the survival horror experience is entering the unknown, and having to do the cost benefit analysis of risking using supplies versus future need for those supplies. This experience cannot be replicated on repeat playthroughs, and contributes greatly to the horror experience. Here is some spoiler free advice for newer players who might want to take on the challenge of playing this game for the first time on hard which will ensure a more smooth playing experience:

Create multiple savesHaving 20 save slots means that you can create backups to go back to in case you trap yourself in a corner. Going back 3 or even 4 saves is not as dreadful as it might seem since a great deal of play time is trial and error solution finding. A part that might have took you an hour to get through might take 20 minutes or less when you know what items you need and can save time on backtracking. Never put all your saves in one file or you might get irreversibly stuck.

Use handgun bullets on zombies whenever possible, save the better stuff for the bigger threatsZombies are the low level mooks of this game, and despite what I said earlier, there are usually more handgun bullets than you need. The problem isn't just having ammo, its having the right ammo for the right enemies. Its usually not worth wasting a grenade on a zombie, there are bigger and badder things around the corner that will demand that firepower. A way to make handgun bullets more effective is to bring your partner character with you and have both of them equipped with handguns. Let Billy be the supporting AI since he has more health and shoots more agressively.

There is more gas than there are bottles to turn into molotovs, don't bother lugging gas cans around. Molotovs are also nearly useless, and don't make that much of a difference This is another flaw of this game. The game leads you to believe that gas is important enough to carry around with you, but it can only create molotovs and there is more of it than you need, which is usually placed around empty bottles in the first place. Any gas you don't immediately use you can almost always ditch. Another thing is that the molotovs are very poor weapons. The attack animation is too slow, the throw range is inconsistent and they don't do very much damage. They are most useful when you encounter leech monsters for the first time, who will often go through a transformation sequence. This gives you a window of time to throw 3-4 molotovs on them guaranteeing their death, but even then they might still get a good hit on you. It might be better to just avoid the leech monsters entirely if you can.

Keep the hookshot nearby after the train section, it will be needed again later. After the lab is complete, you can safely leave it behind, opening up two whole slots in your characters inventory This always gets people. There is a weird gap after the first section of the game where you use the hookshot once, and then never need it again for the next map. You will need it multiple times in the next map following that one though and people will often leave it all the way back at the beginning of the previous map. Once that section is done though you can ditch it for good, unlike other key items it does not disappear after it no longer serves any use.

Good luck, have fun, and enjoy true survival horror!

reviewText:
I've had an amazing time with this game. Being a massive fan of the RE series, especially  the more 'classic' style games, this was the best thing I've played since, well, REmake HD to be honest. The partner mechanic mixed with the limited inventory system makes for some interesting tactical choices. I found myself unequipping the useless AI and using them as a pack mule, using my armed character to scout ahead and my then bringing in the unequipped character as a pack mule. Unfortunately when buddied up, the partner AI is prone to wasting ammo and running straight into the enemies arms and is one of the few cons i have against the game.

In regards to the inventory management, the ability to drop items is a mixed blessing. While I didnt suffer too much backtracking, I did have to cart myself all the way to an area I visited hours ago as I hadn't been able to bring my grenade launcher with me. With it being just before the final boss, it killed my momentum a little. That said, it does add more depth to the gameplay than the 'magic box' system favoured by the other classic titles and goes a long way to underlining the survival aspect of Survival Horror.

My playthrough took me 6 in game hours (according to my ranking at the end) or around 8-9 actual hours with deaths and reloads. I found that Normal was actually quite challening, more so than REmake HD. In fact Zero is up there with Code Veronica as personally what I believe to be the most challenging games in the series. With that in mind though the tougher than average difficulty really helped keep me invested in the game. If like me, its your first time playing this since the Gamecube days, then you arent going to have a lot of surplus ammo or healing items even by the end boss. I appreciated this personally, as I find with most RE games, the difficulty drops off sharply after the first half, by which point the 'magic box' has enough ammo and herbs in to last for another full playthough.

Graphically, I can't fault the presentation at all. While being less atmospheric that REmake, the environments still sing with the HD makeover. Character models, lighting and shadows are all very immersive too. With everything maxed my mid range PC never struggled to keep a 60hz refresh rate.

In terms of story, its probably one of the weaker of the series to be honest. It perhaps takes itself too seriously compared to the more 'B-Movie' values of the earlier installments. The story is serviceable but in all honesty, as a prequel it fails to tell us anything that would be integral to the understanding of the plot of the subsequent games. Dialog and cutscenes are actually quite sparse and it would have probably benefitted the game to have more interaction between the 2 playable characters. As it stands, they barely say a word to each other once their characters have been established.

There's plenty more I could say but the most important thing is I strongly reccomend the game. I actually enjoyed it a lot more than I did around 10+ years ago when I first played it. If you have the determination and the patience this is a great title thats more than worth the budget price.

reviewText:
Not the longest nor the deepest of the episodes of this series, but certainly one of the more inventive. Back in the day, 0 introduced the concept of the leeches that could not only work together very intelligently, but also come together to form a new enemy with extra endurance and reach than the others. The hook shot was also another interesting addition, which offered new and more realistic ways to deal with problems in the environment, caused by the enemies, or due to the need to climb to higher surfaces to unlock places that either Rebecca or Billy cannot go. The ability to place items in random places when inventory space is needed are more realistic and intuitive features that would have made previous resident evil games a  little easier to handle.

The story  is well written, albeit brief and very confined to the most essential details. Expanded, they could have made a better narrative. As it is, the tale is well told and gives adventurers items of interest, if only a few. The voices for Rebecca and Billy are well cast and the main villain is pleasingly sinister, albeit underused.

0 is, overall, an atmospheric game that will entertain fans and newcomers alike, but it may seem a little too short. If you want a longer, more in depth experience, seek out Resident Evil 4 or 6. This title is stimulating while it lasts and Wesker mode offers some replay value, but you won't return after having completed all the difficulty levels.

reviewText:
A good port, good HD Remaster, but Resident Evil 0 was not that great to begin with.

Sure, It's an oldschool-style Resident Evil just like the first three games but I find this one boring. It's similar to the first Resident Evil game where you solve puzzles in a huge building, this time it's a facility instead of a mansion. It's good to have two characters that following each other everywhere and solve puzzles together but it's not a new feature for people who played modern titles like RE5 and RE6.

AI of the other character is VERY VERY DUMB. You cannot rely on your partner at all when it comes to combat. They aren't even smart enough to use a gun in their hands. They might help you shoot at enemies once in awhile though.

Unlike RE1-4, there's no storage chest in this game. Really? Yes! the game forces to to throw away items to the floor. You have 6 item slots on each character and most of the heavy weapons required 2 slots to carry, so... another slot for bullets and you have one free slot to carry something else. Have fun running back and forth to pick up items.

The good thing is, it's a very good port. No problem at all on my system, with highest settings. Maybe you'll have a little trouble with the control schemes because the game doesn't allow you to remap buttons manually. It has 5-6 types of control for you to choose but none of them are close to the PS1 version of RE1-3 so if you prefer to control the characters like those games you'll be disappointed. Of course you can solve this issue by using some 3rd party controller mapper.

Should you buy this game? If you like RE1-3, you'll like it, but if you hate RE1-3, you'll hate it.

I give it a 6/10. It's worth playing to complete the story of the Resident Evil series but if you're not a hardcore RE fan it doesn't really mean anything.

reviewText:
After the success of the remaster of the remade Resident Evil, CAPCOM dove back into the archives and remastered Resident Evil 0 (which was developed on the same engine for the Gamecube).

One thing that can be said right off the bat is just how much a work of art the game really is. One of the beauties of this genre and franchise originally was the highly detailed static environments of the original mansion and subsequent environs. When given the level of time, adding on top of that would seem like a rare success but in this case CAPCOM's team emphasized this perfectly. From the train to the training facility and everything thereafter, the player is inundated with shadowplay, detail and an overall enjoyable atmospheric experience. There are some elements that actually look pixelated such as the fireplace in the training facility off the balcony, but they are so rare that they needn't be mentioned.

The sound mastery and soundtrack itself are, yet again, another original that was simply touched up and gained greater eminence because of it. The theme to the training facility might be my favorite track from all of the Resident Evils. It encapsulates that feeling of being trapped in a large, eery place with such perfection. You can hear it 100 times and it still retains, if builds upon, it's original quality. And like many of the franchises' best from pre-RE5, the rest of the soundtrack holds a similar quality that helps create the sensory immersion and atmosphere that made the original so great.

Gameplay wise, it is just as the original which really means not complicated in the least. Very straightforward, and for some, a little sluggish. But not too much so to where it isn't enjoyable even for those who are used to variations on the modern FPS.

The negative aspects of the game really only come from a previous memory of the game. For instance, the faces of Rebecca and Billy have been touched up in certain areas and definitely seem different from the game I remember as a kid. Same can be said with the in-menu faces above the item slots. Also, the FMVs during cutscenes do look slightly dated, but not to the point where it detracts from the story or the game itself.


While I may be a little biased I still give it a solid 8/10 for being shrewdly touched-up version of the original, which supplanted itself in my mind as a child as one of the best horror games ever created.

reviewText:
As an avid Resident Evil fan I'm honestly disappointed by this game, having played every RE title except Outbreak and handheld crap I needed this in my catalog, unfortunately it wasn't a fulfilling experience. Since this is my first time playing it, I can't say much about how good the remastering is, but the game looks good, so that's not a problem.

Firstly, the game isn't too bad, there are a lot of returning elements and joys from the old-school Resident Evils with a few new ideas.
What I liked: removing item boxes from the game was a weird move, but it adds to the survival aspect, you can't carry everything around, you must leave items behind and come back for them etc. The only problem with this is that you can only move your items one by one which is very annoying. In that aspect the item box wins. Outside of that the game sometimes nails how a survival horror game should play out and you can have a great time playing it.
And they actually made the alternate controlls feel better than the RE 1 Remaster, I liked that a lot.

Now the bad: The partner system was interesting at the first glance, I'm not against new mechanics, I think RE has proved with RE 4 that a franchise can bring in a lot of stuff in a new game and make something great while staying true to the franchise. But the partner system is one hell of a mess. Let's put it this way: your partner is close to useless. Sometimes you can shoot zombies together and it's working out, but they are too dumb and robotic. It's worse than RE 5 even, but in RE 5 you can at least play in co-op to eliminate the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ AI. The biggest problem: It just can't dodge anything. I mean I don't expect it to do anything when it's cornered, but when it's open space and all it has to do is follow me back in the room to create some space and it still gets grabbed by a zombie it's just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t. When you bring it to a small room with multiple enemies (which isn't too rare) it's useless. I found myself just using it as a pack-horse and not bringing it to any fights.

So, the partner system is a great failure, the other thing is: enemies. Now don't get me wrong, the enemies are well-designed (except the monkeys, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ those) and the game has good variety. The problem is there are too many of them. Almost every room has at least 2-3 enemies, and with your partner being a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ multiple enemy encounters are a nightmare. I get that they wanted more enemies since you're not alone anymore, but when your other half is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and can't do anything by itself it feels like getting a tumour.

Also, the main characters have no chemistry between them, and one of them is as complex as making a toast, they were just threw together for the sake of it. Same as RE 5, shame.

These things together ruin the whole game, they just couldn't make the partner system work, while the game tries to compliment it. I'm honestly surprised this game sits at the same score as RE 1 on Steam, and that the negative reviews are just pummeled to the ground votewise. Overall, you may enjoy this, as it's not the most horrible game, but I can't recommend this.

reviewText:
This one is tricky.

As Zero is not my favorite [old] RE game, that will forever fall on RE2, I find myself loving and then ... not so much at times. I haven't played this particular game since 2003 or so, so the old RE play style takes some getting used to again. It's survival horror / puzzle / jump scare / etc and thats what made me love the older RE titles. That is intact, and upgraded, and the modern control scheme makes on hell of a difference. Though all of the old gripes are still there. As an 'HD Remaster' it looks fatastic, even if the cut sceens are just upscaled versions of the original, the game itself is pretty as pie. It doesnt feel like a cheap reskin like a lot of other 'HD' re-releases.

Being that most of the puzzles after the first 10 minutes require you to switch back and forth between the two main characters, is not only frustrating at times, but utimately begs for a mutiplayer / co-op mechanic. There is none, there never was. Thankfully there is no real need for partner AI, other than 'Don't waste all the damn ammo' which you have control over. Another annoying, though expected of the series, some of the puzzles are not nearly as self explainitory as you would think. Sometimes they require you to be literally in two places at once, and after learning that you have to backtrack a character.

The inventory in this particular game, is well, horid. You have 6 slots for each character, 12 in total, and at minimum 2 from each are for a weapon, and applicable ammo. To say nothing of health items and puzzle items, which you will be endlessly juggling back and forth when you absolutely need all of the things, then backtrack to pick up whatever you had to leave behind. Old gripe, but could have used some tweaking.

Technically speaking, the game need a little work. My machine meets / exceeds the recommended specs, and there are some sections, mainly around smokey / foggy areas, where it slows to a crawl. I dropped the resoltion to 1280, and the visuals to medium to compensate. Which still looks good, but is NOT why I re-bought a game that I owned over a decade ago.

All things considered, I still favor this entry to the series over literally ANY of the later games, as they have long forgotten there survival-horror roots, which is ltteraly the only reason I liked the older games to begin with. Omg ... 5 was f**king terrible. I am happy that they are making a return in these 'Remake' versions, and I look forward to playing RE1:HD after I complete this one. And RE2:HD if it's not just a rumor (fingers crossed).

If your an old fan of the series, I'd say buy it. Even if it isn't as great as the others, it's still a solid pass. If you like the later, more 'action-y' entries, this probably isn't for you.

This review is based on my game time with the Wii HD remake and the PS4 HD remake.
Resident Evil Zero, many people did not think the game would come to PC but by asking Capcom to bring this gem back to a modern audience and bring the game to PC everyone finally gets to experience a unique Resident Evil experience.
In Resident Evil Zero you take initial control of Rebecca Chamber the young medic from the Bravo team of Resident Evil 1 and who was also the partner of Chris in his scenario.
After some game time you will then team up Rebecca with a new character Billy Coen a former American Army Lieutenant who was being transported to a military base for execution for war crimes.
An uneasy alliance forced the two of them to work together for mutual survival and along the way we learn more about both the characters and what lead them to this situation.
The focuses of a co-op game play where you control either Billy Coen who is resistant to damage and does slightly more damage than Rebecca.
Rebecca on the other hand is quicker than Billy but she takes more damage from hits, her damage is slightly weaker but she is also the only one who can mix herbs as Billy cannot create herb mixtures.
It has all the classic Resident Evil elements of puzzles, monsters and bosses to battle and with the co-op game play sometimes you need to separate from your ally and work to solve the puzzle such as boosting Rebecca with Billy so she can go through a vent.
If you enjoy classic Resident Evil game play I highly recommend this game and with Capcom listening to its audience then maybe we can get a few more classic Resident Evil like games if Capcom sees there is a clambering audience for the classic Resident Evil games and less for games like Resident Evil 5 and 6.
We might even get Resident Evil: Outbreak HD for pc, if Capcom sees there is an audience for the game.

Man.. This game..

It certainly needs no introduction, everyone knows the resident evil saga, and the most appreciate its early titles more than the last ones. I honestly like both (my most played game on steam is RE: Revelations 2 and I played... a lot of RE: Revelations not on steam) for different reason.

I really liked this Resident Evil 0 a lot, I don't care if it's a remastered version of an old game (that's one of the reason i bought it, since i've never had a Gamecube, like most of the people i guess).
The thing about this game, or the first RE, is that is difficoult.. very very difficoult, but not like Dark Souls; it is difficoult in a better way (i like Dark Souls too btw). There are no monster that oneshots you and you can't die by falling from somewhere high, the reason this game is difficoult are the same of some other RE games: you are a human (which means that you actually die pretty fast if a zombie eats your face), there's an extremely lack of ammo of any type and the puzzles are great.

So why this game is so good? Because it's extremely challenging, which means that when you succeed in doing something, like finish a puzzle, or go through a zone with a lot of enemy without using any bullet, you feel litteraly amazing! This game gives you a sense of satisfaction like I've rarely seen in other games. I've litteraly found myself cheering after beating a boss or something like that.

By saying this I'm also saying that this game is extremely immersive, I really felt thrilled for almost the entire duration of the game, and this is just awesome, and i also think that this helps a lot since it's a survival horror game.
In my opinion a good survival horror needs to be this way, it needs to keep you attached to the monitor, it needs to scare you without jumpscare, and this is important. This game scares you, without any jumpscare, but thanks to the atmosphere, the settings, the music and the sounds in general. Everything is exactly where it's supposed to be.

And last but not the least, it's a RE game.. so even the files and the documents you find during the game are very interesting for the sake of the entire RE history, especially if , like me, you've never played RE zero before.

So probably the fact that I'm a huge fan of the saga helped me a lot enjoying this game, but still I think it's a great game, which everyone who like a genuine survival horror should definetely try out.

reviewText:
When I heard Capcom is going to release Resident Evil 0, I immediately knew this game is going to be a must have for me, because - among many other things - I always wanted to know and experience what happened before the original Resident Evil. Since I've never owned a video game console, I envied those who had the opportunity to play amazing titles that were exclusive to consoles, such as Dead Space 2: Severed, Drakan: The Ancients' Gates and Condemned 2. And of course Resident Evil 0.

After playing it through, I can now understand what an experience it must have been for those who had a Gamecube (the original console it came out to first in 2002) back then. In 2016 it still is incredibly enjoyable. Everything is in place: spooky atmosphere, beautiful underground locations, logical, but sometimes unrealistic puzzles, naive but loveable characters, the herbs, and everything the Resident Evil series is known of.

The game follows the old school Resident Evil scheme from RE 1, 2 and 3. That being said, there are semi-fixed camera positions (there are locations where it follows the character) from a perspective of a monster, which adds to the horror sensation (introduced by the great Alone in the Dark from 1992) and console based controls (good advice: if you want to enjoy the game, get a controller and make sure it's heavy).

The protagonist of the game is Rebecca Chambers, a young medical officer, the girl trapped in one of the rooms from the original Resident Evil. I dare to say she is one of the most loveable characters in gaming history, even though she is a pretty standard Japanese-made female character. Her naiveness and surprised looks can charm even female gamers who would otherwise find her irritating. Not long after the beginning she is joined by an ex-marine, Billy, who had apparently been sentenced to death for murder. After a thrilling zombie infested train ride, the duo begins to investigate an abandoned facility (very similar to the manor from Resident Evil) and of course to escape with their lives.

The story as far as the Resident Evil series go, is very good and we can finally discover how it all started: who was the creator of the T-virus, what species it was tested on originally, how did famous characters, such as Wesker come into play and so on. We get a pretty detailed background in Resident Evil lore.

The greatest improvement of the game is the partner system. Almost through the entire game the player gets to control both Rebecca and Billy. Of course only one at a time, but switching between the two is almost immediate. Switching and using them separately is sometimes vital for solving puzzles (pushing two buttons at the same time, etc.). In combat having a partner is also useful, even though in some places it is advised to leave the other one behind, because having two characters also means taking double damage. The attributes of Rebecca and Billy are also different (altough only slightly): Rebecca can mix things (in the other RE games everyone was capable of doing this) and can fit into smaller places, while Billy takes less damage from attacks and can push heavier objects (the latter is used only once throughout the entire game).
The other thing to point out is that you can leave things anywhere (ther are no chests as in RE 1-3), which is a good and a bad thing. Good because with the very limited inventory you can't carry much and you can leave stuff whereever you want to, but it also means that you can't access it later from a storage chest and all you can do is backtrack (even though the items appear on the map). There are also things you have to keep for a long time, the hookshot for example, a tool that takes up 1/3 of your inventory space (you should only throw it away when you find the Magnum in the tram).

The creators came up with quite a lot of new enemies, the leeches above all. As seen in the intro, these little infected creatures are going to stir up a lot of trouble. Besides the good old RE enemies (zombie dobermans, hunters, crows) there are plenty or arch enemies as well, that are all creative enough, but I still liked the ones from the original better. In point of weapons the only new thing here is the molotov cocktail (Billy can also mix this) made of gasoline and empty bottles (so if you find any, mix them immediately) and it's useful against a certain type of enemy (one that is very hard to kill otherwise ;)).

Graphically the game is astonishing. reviewText:
Until the day of writing this, Resident Evil: 0 was the one Resident Evil title I'd never played. After delving into this blind, I can safely give off several first impressions. To preface this, however, if you love survival horror or the Resident Evil series, then buy this right away. That said, to add more incentive here are the following pros:

+Better item management than the entire series. This game does away with item boxes and allows you to leave items in a location, handily marked on your map, and retrieve it at any time. There's also your partner's inventory, which you can trade items with back and forth at your leisure.

+Bosses. Within the first ten minutes the game will have thrown its first boss at you. My opponent was a giant scorpion made of leeches, and due to my blind foray into the game, I had no weapons on me. What followed was a breathtaking, heart-pumping fight for survival where my knife held me through adversity. A feeling I haven't felt since the original 2002 release of last year's Resident Evil: REmake.

+Characters. Billy Coen, hands down is the best male protagonist in the Resident Evil series. His past a mystery, the true nature of his placement as a prisoner on the ecliptic express reveals a backstory of melancholy and betrayal. Capcom nailed it with his motivations, and his portrayal. Rebecca is a much loved character from Resident Evil 1, and if you loved her in that, her stepping into the spotlight in this game will satisfy you.

+Enemy design. With a much more diverse sideshow of enemies to battle and run from than its predecessor game, Zero offfers an abundance of grisly and challenging foes that are sure to plague your nightmares. Giant scorpions, leech men, to the cerberus that's become iconic in itself. Each room offers a challenge and an opportunity to encounter only the most fearsome of Umbrella's dark experiments.

+Controls. The initial control system was rather iffy, but only because it was different to REmake. To my joy, there are three control configurations as well as the default, and control type D plays just like last year's REmake remaster. This game has done away with tank controls, and it feels good.

+Set pieces. Can't go into detail much, but if you ever thought you wouldn't have a countdown to an explosion early into an RE game, this game changes everything.

Cons:

- Same audio as the original release: It's quite jarring that in such a pretty, upscaled and retouched environment the sounds are still as weathered and old as the game's age itself. This is particularly telling in monster cutscenes, where a door being smacked off of its hinges sounds like several boxes falling off of a shelf.

- Cutscenes haven't been remade. Due to their FMV nature, it's understandable they couldn't be edited. That said, Capcom could at least have upscaled them from 4:3 to 16:9/10 for the sake of visual consistency. Seeing two black boxes at the sides is quite the immersion killer.

Overall, this game gets a 9/10 from me. It's almost as good as REmake, although I will forever maintain that REmake and Resident Evil 3 are the kings of the series. If you're hungry for more Resident Evil, or want a particularly challenging horror game with mechanics ahead of its time, then this is for you.

Thanks for reading, feel free to add me on Steam.

reviewText:
Horror, quite possibly one of the most fun and difficult genres of gaming.  Originating back in the early 1990's on the Playstation One, the Resident Evil One (RE) in the series instantly became the icon for suspense, horror and mystery.  Like all great mysteries, answers to questions get overlooked leaving the player with a thirst un-quenched.  Resident Evil: Zero is that quintessential thirst quencher.  With it's complete fun integrated explanation of game play balanced with all the elements of the series storytelling.  The mystery uncloaked here is a prime example of a prequel meant to be played after having played thru RE:1 first, thus allowing for a  mystery, mystery then answer experience rather than a mystery, answer and mystery solved experience.

Warning: From here on out there are *SPOILERS* so read at your peril. XP

The mystery unveiled by the use of yet more mystery.  Lets quickly run through a brief overview of events to give us some feel for the game and story.  Starting out on  a train of the dead, that being a loose and relative thing, our heroine Rebecca Chambers after a lovely intro cut scene investigates.  Just like the first Resident Evil the player is left with a little to go on except micro-sandbox exploration.  Through the use of occasional scripted scenes a team member of STARS ( the police force Rebecca is on) dies from bites and loss of blood from super leeches and a new character/partner Billy Coen (the so called criminal) is introduced as well as the partner system.  Rebecca is attacked by a person made of leeches whom Billy heroically kills, saving Rebecca.  They team up exploring more of the train, while doing so Rebecca gets trapped after fixing a damaged circuit board on the roof of the train and Billy goes to find a tool to get her out.  On the search he gets attacked by a scorpion the size of a Buick, a mass of leech eggs hatch and our heroes have to stop a now run away train.  Managing to do so only to crash into an underground tunnel in a hillside, they somehow manage to survive.  After taking a minute to recover they proceed, only to discover they are in a mansion of the dead, note this one is different than the one in RE:1.  After several puzzles, zombies and a few new enemies we begin to paint a picture on how this whole chain of events came to be as well as reveal the Men behind the scenes and the role they played leading up to RE:1.  Prior to RE:1, and subsequently RE:0, a scientist discovered a means to immortality in the Progenitor virus and proceeded to experiment on how to make it viable.  Leeches where the key.  He the scientist is revealed to be alive, surprisingly because the two men mentioned earlier killed him.  Rebecca and Billy learn how all three villains got started, their dark experiments and after discovering the underground facility by way of a zip-line car and the Doctors revived form and world destructive plans.  They take on the doctor  kill him escape the self-destruction of the facility that then leads to Rebecca's Role in RE:1.  So, overall the game feels adequate to be a stand alone and also very satisfying as a prequel.  Note the partner system allows some choice on who plays what role in some sequences, while in other sequences it is character specific allowing for character development thru personal experiences thus shaping the story.  Flashbacks also play a small role enriching the experience to fill in any of the gaps literature found thru out the game failed to reveal or simply was missed while playing, for the player.

New and then kept for future games of the RE series was the partner system.  Though other games in the series had points when two characters would be together for short periods of time, they made both playable but never together.  Important to note also is that a player can switch between characters, single character to allow more complex puzzle solving and save time by switching between characters or have the second character (your choice) follow you, select how aggressive you want them to play burning thru ammo or being defensive and save it along with each respective inventory allows a great deal of freedom and customizablility, all showing the care, detail and standards to which this game was made.  In addition by having a secondary character carry a specific weapon you directly select what kind of weapon and ammo they use.  This intuitive function allows characters to be played with together or separately depending on how easy, challenging  the player wants to make it.   Having properly crafted this partner system the game also manages a decent blend of survival horror with it limited but numerous undead, finite ammo, payoffs of close quarters kills along with puzzles that really require as much as attention to detail as curiosity to truly discover all the secrets often with a worth while payoff.   The detective work to uncover the truth gives a rich lore and is a great driving force if not a the challenge of beating the game in general.   Overall, it's the blending of these elements, their timing and placement that keeps the game fresh and the player coming back for more.

Game play is just as good as the original if not slightly more spot on.  Combat is kept honest to the original, basically a 3 level system of up, middle and down attacks with a radial direction and again 3 levels of distance far, medium and close range.  The payoff of range and levels allows for a tactile application of selecting not just targets but relative parts of target Eg. a head shot at close range aimed squarely  and up at the target for max damage/kill shot or medium range with a grenade launcher for a multi kill and no self damage.   General movement controls give that traditional game play of the first RE through a bit wonky/clunky it serves to first add to the terror and suspense in any combat as well as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off the unexperienced furthering the horror experience.

The re-release of this game brought with it updated graphics.  This is always a little bittersweet as it changes the visual feel of the game, though in this case it feels like someone cleaned off the screen allowing a more crisp view.   Hilariously though is that there are 3 levels of graphics in this game, game play graphics in HD, low res graphics of most of the cut scenes and one cut scene which they forgot to update at all making it the most entertaining.  Overall though it feels like a healthy mix of old and updated giving its own unique experience.
The music is identically the same.  Ambient eerie tonal tracks through out the environment help to create the horror without detracting from the immersion with out of place music.  The contrast of the safe rooms' tune emulates a breath of fresh air or a sigh of relief and acts as a synergistic amplifier between rest and tension outside the safe room.

Bonus or extra content considering the premise of the game seems a little out of place, primarily the costumes, which were earned/unlock in previous version of the game.  Rebecca's cheerleader costume in particular is one such case,  the is fully functional and moves relative to her movements, however.  The major drawbacks to every costume is it's absence in movie cut scene's losing some of its appeal.  The new Wesker mode makes Rebecca totally Smoken' hot and pay homage to RE 5's Jill mind control.  In addition Billy is now Wesker and comes with 2 unique abilities Death Vision a chargeable AOE with head shot ability and Super Speed. Yup no more walking or casual jogging, you can dash across rooms with ease, amazingly helpful for speed runs. There is more but I'm out of space

Simply, its a solid game made in an era when games had less graphics and were pushed to be engaging and with lasting depth that will always be memorable.
